awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Collaborative: Leveraging community oversight to enhance collective efficacy for privacy and security
awd_abstract_narration:
This research concerns how groups of people can cooperate to protect their privacy. The researchers will study how people can help one another to manage their digital privacy and security. Offline, people support each other informally to make privacy and security decisions, by sharing stories or exchanging advice, but technology designs for privacy do not reflect these social processes. This project builds on social science research on collective efficacy and citizen participation in problem solving, and develops a model of community oversight to help groups of people collectively manage their digital privacy and security. The researchers will evaluate this model within the context of mobile smartphones, and prototype a mobile app for groups of interconnected users to share and provide feedback regarding a range of mobile privacy and security settings. Research with people will also provide insight into how to support different groups to communicate and collaborate around mobile security and safety.

The willingness of individuals to intervene on others' behalf is known as collective efficacy, and the intention of the model of community oversight is to support and improve this outcome among interconnected individuals or existing communities such as families, friends, co-workers in a manner that enhances their digital privacy and security. The work makes a theoretical contribution by offering a model of community oversight and demonstrating how this model might be translated into sociotechnical design. The user studies will provide valuable insights into the social and technical factors that impact user participation in community oversight for digital privacy and security. Through the implementation and deployment of the mobile app in the field, the researchers will evaluate how users interact with the technology artifact and with each other, providing valuable design guidelines for future systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research has examined how groups of people can cooperate to manage their digital privacy and security. We developed a model of community oversight to help groups of people collectively manage their digital privacy and security. The model identifies the elements of transparency, awareness, community participation, and individual incentives as important components to develop technical systems that can support community oversight. The willingness of individuals to intervene on others' behalf is known as collective efficacy, and the intention of the model of community oversight is to support and improve this outcome among interconnected individuals or existing communities such as families, friends, and co-workers in a manner that enhances their digital privacy and security.

We evaluated the elements of our community oversight model through a series of user studies in existing communities, such as families and older adults. Oversight of digital security and privacy is embedded in the overall activity of tech caregiving, providing informal technical support to one’s social network. Results demonstrate that groups who feel closer to each other do have higher collective efficacy for managing their digital security and privacy together. Our results highlight that educating those who play the role of tech caregivers would enable that information to spread throughout communities. There is also a gap in technologies that support the collective management of privacy and security, to enable caregivers to be aware of the needs of others and support communication.

We designed and developed an Android mobile app that allows small groups of users to collectively manage their mobile app security and privacy. The Community Oversight of Privacy and Security (CO-oPS) app allows groups of users to share the apps they have installed and app permissions they have allowed with each other. Through features providing transparency and awareness of apps and permissions, users are able to learn social norms and perform oversight of others within their community. We found that CO-oPS facilitates communication around mobile security and privacy, and increases collective efficacy for managing apps and permissions. Yet, individuals may not be incentivized to perform oversight of others outside of their existing care structures, such as parents monitoring teens and adults looking out for older parents. Our research demonstrates that taking a community-oriented view of security and privacy can help support users, and provides a series of guidelines for developing technology for community oversight.
